snippet.title: TinyMaths
snippet.description:
I'm here to help you get to the details of math problems. Often we are concerned with getting grades and passing tests, and because things move so fast, we aren't always able to get a deep enough understanding of the subject being studied. 

I'm here to help you with the nuts and bolts of high school maths.

snippet.title: Exam Practice Stopwatch (2-hr, with time-up beeps)
snippet.description:
Use this timer for practice exam papers (last 2  hours with finishing alarm)
Just hit pause the video for precision timing requirements.  If you want to restart the stopwatch; hit the refresh button in the browser to reset the timer. 

Enjoy

#stopwatch#Studyaid#TheTimer#mathexam#exampractice#examtimer

snippet.title: Pomodoro Technique  - 25 minutes study ( 5 minute rests )
snippet.description:
To help you study more efficiently. 

Pomodoro Technique 25 min study, 5 min break. 
5 x 25 min (study)   |   5 x 5 min (relax)

Efficient Study Method for any subject (including math): 
Timer sections: 
0:00:00 - Study session 1
0:25:01 - Pomodoro 1
0:30:02 - Study session 2
0:55:03 - Pomodoro 2
1:00:04 - Study session 3
1:25:05 - Pomodoro 3
1:30:06 - Study session 4
1:55:07 - Pomodoro 4
2:00:08 - Study session 5
2:25:09 - Pomodoro 5


How to use: 
The timer is split into two sections. The first section lasts 25 minutes long; that's when you should be studying; this is then followed by a 5 minute break where you rest from study so you can refresh your mind.  The timer repeats five times so you can study for two and and a half hours interrupted.  Each section's end time is marked with a short alarm to alert you of when a rest or study period is approaching.   This Method will help you study better, and leave you less tired after study .

Enjoy

#Pomodoro #StudyForFuture #TheTimer

snippet.title: Add Fractions - SAME Denominators: Made SIMPLE
snippet.description:
Adding Fractions with the SAME denominators requires an EASY Math technique. In this lesson, you'll learn a step by step process on how to Add and SIMPLIFY fractions with the SAME denominators. 


We'll look at two examples and explain the process for adding the two fractions in both examples. Then, after each example you'll learn how to do the most important steps; how to SIMPLIFY the fraction once you have your answer.  Your teacher will be looking for your to do this so, DON'T MISS THIS STEP! Otherwise you'll lose marks. 

Related Videos:
Learn How To SIMPLIFY Fractions (in more detail) here: 
https://youtu.be/fvLFQ2LXeMk
Also, learn how to ADD fractions with DIFFERENT denominators FAST, here: 
https://youtu.be/cNj6rsyJFPo

#Simple Math #Easy Fractions #Same Denominators #Adding Fractions

What's In This video: 
0:00 - Adding Similar Fractions is SIMPLE
0:18 - Three EASY Steps 
0:46 - Example 1
1:54 - Example 2
2:51 - Remember The 3 Steps

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: Subtract Mixed Numbers How To
snippet.description:
Hey Guys, Tiny Maths Back with another video: Today we're learning how to subtract mixed numbers. 
We'll be looking at these two examples: 


1(7/9) - 1(2/3)
8(1/5) - 3(7/10)


To be good at subtracting Mixed numbers you'll need to have the following basic skills; 
1) Convert Mixed Numbers to improper fractions.
2) Find the LCD of two fractions and create EQUIVALENT fractions using the LCD
3) Convert Improper Fractions to Mixed Numbers
4) Simplify (or reduce) Proper Fractions
Links to my video lessons on these subjects can be found in the description. 




Convert Mixed Numbers To Fractions - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tc-6kYGZ1ak
Find Lowest Common Denominators - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v79EPbER--g
Improper Fractions To Mixed Numbers - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TwuSyq2piVY
Simplify Fractions - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk




There are 4 steps to subtracting mixed numbers. 
1. Convert Mixed numbers to improper fractions
2. Find the LCD of the resulting fractions and convert both to EQUIVALENT fractions using the LCD.
3. Do the subtraction using the fractions.
4. Depending on the result, simplify or convert to a mixed number as required.


This is one of the several videos in the series for Mixed Numbers; you can see the other videos in the Mixed Numbers Playlist, linked here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0s2mDamPID8&list=PLg0VaWkoZqUzG3cAfF3kvkXdpRSzDJAuM




Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1




Contents: 
0:00 - What’s in the video / What You Should Already Know.
0:35 - The 4-Step Method
1:01 - Example 1  
4:25 - Example 2
7:58 - Recap and Useful Videos

snippet.title: Convert IMPROPER fractions to MIXED numbers
snippet.description:
Hi Guys TinyMaths here. Today we'll be learning how to Convert Improper Fractions to Mixed numbers. 
We'll be converting these two examples -  10/9 -  5/2. These fractions are improper since, for both of them, the numerator is larger than the denominator; 10 is larger than 9, and 5 is larger than 2.  Normally, when taking tests and answering questions involving fractions, if the result you get is an improper fraction, you will be expected to convert it to a mixed number.  A mixed number is just a number that is made up of two elements, a whole number and a fraction.

In today's lesson we'll see that Improper Fractions are really just Mixed Numbers in disguise. Improper fractions and mixed numbers are just the same value written in two different ways. In order to do this effectively you will need to know how to do simple division and with our two examples, 10/9 and 5/2, we'll see exactly how division is used to convert the improper fractions to an equivalent mixed number. 

This video is part of a series on mixed numbers which will give you a good overall understanding of mixed numbers so that you will be able to manage questions that involve these types of numbers. I've linked to them all below and there are onscreen video links at the end of this video.  Enjoy


Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1


Other videos included in this series on Mixed Numbers:

Divide Mixed Numbers How: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0s2mDamPID8

How To Multiply Mixed Numbers: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_zRTJ_fWUK0

How To Add Mixed Numbers With Different Denominators:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IEsYDsPsrsQ

How To Convert Mixed Numbers To Fractions:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tc-6kYGZ1ak

Contents: 

0:00 - About Improper Fractions - Why convert them?
0:51 - Improper Fractions ARE ALREADY Mixed Numbers 
2:23 - Converting 10/9
3:29 - Converting 5/2
4:08 - Summary and other useful videos

snippet.title: Divide Mixed Numbers   How
snippet.description:
Hey Guys, Tiny Maths Back with another video: Today we're learning how to Divide mixed numbers. 
We'll be looking at these two examples: 

One and Two Thirds divided by One and a Half
Two and a Half divided by three and three quarters. 

There are a few things you should already know, if you're hoping to divide mixed numbers easily:  

1) How to write mixed numbers as improper fractions.
2) How to Divide and Multiply fractions.  
3) how to use cross cancellation to reduce fractions before multiplying. 
I've made videos on all these topics, and they're linked here in the description if you need to refresh your memory: 

How To Convert Mixed Numbers To Improper Fractions - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tc-6kYGZ1ak

How To Divide Fractions - 
https://youtu.be/BByV9Hr1O-c

How To Multiply Fractions Using Cancellation - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQPEa6Abk-0



There are 3 simples steps to  mixed numbers. 
1. Convert Mixed numbers to improper fractions
2. Invert the dividing fraction and use multiplication instead.
4. Simplify the result if the fraction is improper, or convert to a mixed number if improper.

This lesson is a good addition to the previous lesson where I show you how to multiply mixed numbers so I'll link it here if you would like to go back and watch that too. 

Thanks for watching and please feel free to comment and ask any questions on this topic in the comment sections.

snippet.title: How To Multiply Mixed Numbers
snippet.description:
Hey Guys, Tiny Maths Back with another video: Today we're learning how to multiply mixed numbers. 
We'll be looking at these two examples: 

1-1/4 x 1-2/3
8-1/3 x 3-1/10

In order to multiply mixed numbers should know the following two things; 
1) How to write mixed numbers as improper fractions.
2) How to multiply fractions.  
3) how to use cross cancellation to reduce fractions before multiplying. 
I've made videos on these three subjects if you need a refresher; they are linked here: 

How To Convert Mixed Numbers To Improper Fractions - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tc-6kYGZ1ak

How To Multiply Fractions Using Cancellation: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQPEa6Abk-0

There are 3 simples steps to multiplying mixed numbers. 
1. Convert Mixed numbers to improper fractions
2. Multiply the Fractions
3. Convert the result back to a mixed number

We'll show you how to use these steps to multiply the mixed numbers in our two examples - The next lesson will be on how to divide mixed numbers, so keep an eye out for that lesson coming soon.

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to ask in the comment section: 

Enjoy.

snippet.title: Recurring Decimals To Fractions
snippet.description:
Hey Guys, TinyMaths here, back with another lesson. Today we are looking at how to convert recurring decimals to fractions. We’ll be converting these examples:

0.6262626262...
3.626262626262.....
0.27626262626262...
0.21586586586586....

 A recurring decimal is a number, where, after the decimal there is a pattern of numbers that repeat over and over again forever.  We'll consider two kinds. Firstly where the recurrence happens immediately after the decimal point, and then another situation, where immediately after the decimal point, there are some non-repeating numbers, and then the numbers after those repeat over and over again forever. 

These methods share some similarities with my previous video where I showed you how to convert normal decimals to fractions; so it would be useful for you to review that video; I'll link it below. 

Hopefully by the end of the lesson you will be able to convert recurring decimals to fractions, not only where the value is less than one, but also where there are mixed numbers so you have whole numbers before the decimal and recurring numbers after the decimal.  

I don't simplify any of the fractions that I convert from recurring decimals here because they are quite hard to simplify, but if you wish to give them a try, you might want to watch my tutorial on simplifying fractions first, below: 

Video: Convert Decimals To Fractions - https://youtu.be/sil74Qa6vzQ

Here's my video “ How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization”,  if you need a refresher lesson:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk


If you have any questions please don't hesitate to ask in the comment section: 

Enjoy.

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: How To Convert Decimals To Fractions
snippet.description:
Hey guys; TinyMaths here, back with another video.  In today’s lesson you’ll be learning how to convert decimals into fractions. It’s a 5 step process which, once you’ve learned it, will make converting decimals to fractions quite straightforward. 

We'll be using three examples: 0.62, 0.243 and 3.62

These are the 5 steps you'll need to follow. 

1. Give the decimal a label 'X'
2. Turn the Decimal into a whole number by multiplying it by a power of 10. (use 10 to the power of how many decimal places your number is; for example, if your number is 0.245, since there are 3 decimals, you would multiply this number by 10 to the power of 3 which is 1000.  That will give you the number 245, and then you write the equation 0.245 x 1000 = 245)

3. Replace the decimal with its label 'X' in the equation you created
4. Find the value of 'X' by dividing both sides of the equation to get X on its own (this should give you that X on the left hand side is equal to a fraction on the right hand side). 
5. Replace 'X' with the original decimal and you should have your result; the decimal on the left hand side of the equals sign and a fraction on the right side of the equals sign. The conversion is complete. 

You will also need to know how to simplify fractions since your final fraction will likely have large numbers for numerator and denominator. 

Here's my video “ How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization”,  if you need a refresher lesson:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk


Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

Contents: 
What's In This lesson - 
0:25 Example 1 - Converting 0.62
2:49 Which power of 10?
3:25 Example 2 - Converting 0.243
4:47 Example 3 - Converting 3.62
6:32 What's in the next lesson?

snippet.title: How To Convert Mixed Numbers To Fractions
snippet.description:
Today we are going to be learning how to convert mixed numbers into fractions.  By the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to use four simple steps to convert ANY mixed number you come across. Basically a mixed number is a number that is made up of two different parts; one part of the mixed number is a whole number and the other part is a fraction; actually a proper fraction where the denominator is a bigger number than the numerator

Mixed numbers can be re-written as fractions.  An important thing to remember is that once you’ve re-written a mixed number, the resulting fraction should be an improper fraction

There are four simple steps to converting Mixed Numbers to Improper Fractions; here they are below: 

STEPS: 
1)Take a copy of the numerator of the fraction to the RHS 
2) Take a copy of the denominator of the fraction to the RHS
3) Multiply the Whole Number by the original denominator.
4) Add the result you got in step 3 to the RHS numerator.

These steps must result in improper fractions. 

We’ll convert two examples; I’ll give the mixed numbers and their equivalents below and during the lesson you will see exactly how I do the conversions of the mixed numbers and arrive at the fractions: 

Example 1 - 4 ½ = 9/2
Example 2 -  5 ⅔ = 17/3

At the end of the lesson I’ll leave some examples for you to try and you can write the answers in the comment section if you want to.  

I’ve also done a different lesson on Mixed Numbers where I teach how to add two Mixed Numbers - here is the link: 

How To Add Mixed Numbers With Different Denominators - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IEsYDsPsrsQ

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: How To Divide Fractions
snippet.description:
Today we’ll be learning how to divide fractions. 
This lesson has 2 stages to it.  In the first stage, I will describe the method for dividing fractions. In the second stage we’ll work on a few  examples to see how the process is used.


You'll need to know how to multiply fractions in order to use this process and, just in case you can't remember how that's done, I attach my lesson here so you can check it out: here it is - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DQPEa6Abk-0

We'll show you how the process works by using the example 2/3 divided by 1/2 and once we've got the answer I'll show you with a visual representation that the method actually works. 

We will then look at two other examples with a slight variation 6 divided by 9/4 where we are dividing a whole number by a fraction,  and, 6/7 divided by 2 where we are dividing a fraction by a whole number.  

By the end of the lesson you will have covered the basic situations where you will need to use division with fractions. 

Well, hope you enjoy the lesson

Until the next video

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

snippet.title: How To Multiply Fractions by WHOLE NUMBERS
snippet.description:
Hey All, TinyMaths here, back with another video. In today’s lesson we’ll be looking at how to multiply fractions by whole numbers..  There’s a few things you’ll need to know in order for you to understand this lesson.  

What you need to know. 
Know how to find common factors with prime factorization or other methods
How to simplify fractions
How to Convert Improper Fractions to Mixed Numbers

If you need to refresh your memory on how to do these I’ve linked my previous videos covering these subjects here; 

How To Find The HCF of Two Numbers  Using Prime Factorization
https://youtu.be/vHVVs-COFKA


How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk

How To Add Mixed Numbers With Different Denominators - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IEsYDsPsrsQ


In this lesson we’ll be examining two methods of adding multiplying fractions with whole numbers. The first method is listed below: 

Multiply the whole number by the numerator (becomes the new numerator)
Do nothing to the denominator; just take it to the other side 
For the new fraction; If the fraction is improper then convert to a mixed number/ if it is a proper fraction, simplify where possible. 

Well use this method to solve the problem 6*4/9. 
Then we’ll discuss the following problem; 54*24/92. It will become clear that this is more difficult. And then we will show the following method which makes this kind of problem easier. Here are the steps - 

If the fraction can be simplified, do so. 
Then, if the whole number and denominator of the fraction share any factors, Using cancellation, divide both by the highest one, the HCF.  
Then, use the simple method described before 

This will make the more difficult problem much easier, Finally, we will also use this second method to solve the initial problem of 6*4/9.  Hopefully you will find both of these methods useful, but I recommend using the second method if you have to multiply large numbers or if your fraction contains large numbers; you’ll find it much easier to break it down to the second method.  The next video will be on how to divide fractions, which should be easy to follow if you thoroughly study this lesson.  Thanks for watching. 



Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

Contents: 
0:00 - What's In This Lesson?
0:26 - Basic Method (3 steps) - Method 1
1:00 - Easy Example with basic method (6*4/9)
2:18 - Problems With The Basic Method 
3:05 - Method 2 With Harder Example (56*24/92)
7:31 - Method 2 With Easy Example (6*4/9)
9:06 - Summary of Method 2 Steps

snippet.title: How To Multiply Fractions Using Cancellation
snippet.description:
Hey All, TinyMaths here, back with another video. In today’s lesson we’ll be looking at how to multiply fractions.  There’s a few things you’ll need to know in order for you to understand this lesson.  

What you need to know. 
Know how to find common factors.
How to simplify fractions
(optional) How to do prime factorization on whole numbers

If you need to refresh your memory on how to do these I’ve linked my previous videos covering these subjects here; 

How To Find The HCF of Two Numbers  Using Prime Factorization
https://youtu.be/vHVVs-COFKA


How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk

What Is Prime Factorization?
https://youtu.be/1MPnDudbMow

When learning how to multiply fractions, there’s one rule you need to know, and that’s multiply horizontally, multiply numerators by numerators and that becomes your new numerator, and then multiply denominators by denominators and that becomes your new denominator. That new Numerator and Denominator are the parts of your Fraction resulting from the two multiplied fractions.  Sometimes, the resulting fraction might need simplifying, or if it’s an improper fraction you’ll have to convert it to a mixed number.  We’ll learn this process in today’s lesson.  

We’ll work on two problems, firstly, 2/4 * 6/7, and then 3/14*20/36 and use the following process to solve both problems. 

Simplify Fractions where possible
Use cross cancellation to eliminate any remaining shared factors.
Multiply the resulting fractions. 

I’ll explain how this works in detail and you will see that, with these additional steps, multiplying fractions is not too difficult. 

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

3:32 - Example 1b - (2/4 x 6/7)  - Alternative Method
5:49 - Example 2 - (3/14 x 20/36) - Alternative Method
8:07 - Summary and Other Useful Videos

snippet.title: Equivalent Fractions Explained
snippet.description:
Hey Guys. In today's lesson Equivalent Fractions will be explained.  By the end of Today's lesson, you will understand: 
- What equivalent Fractions Are
- How To Create Them, and
- Where They Are Used

We'll look at several fractions that appear different but that are all equivalent to 1/2. We'll show this using simple shapes and then we'll show how each fraction compares to 1/2 and we'll also discuss how the ratio between a fraction's numerator and denominator tell us if it is equivalent to other fractions. 

We will also consider two fractions 19/25 and 1120/1750 and show that, although they appear to be completely different, they are actually equivalent to each other.  By the end of the lesson you will understand why this is clearly the case. 

Finally we will look at two situations where knowledge of Equivalent Fractions is very useful.  Firstly where we have to add dissimilar fractions, and then when we have to reduce a fraction to its simplest form. 

I'll also recommend other videos where you can see directly how equivalent fractions can be used. 

The two recommended videos are detailed below and you should watch them 'after' this video lesson. 

 Recommended Videos: 
How To Add Fractions with Different Denominators Using Lowest Common Multiples -
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eAmiqZLrhnI&t=481s

How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization - 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fvLFQ2LXeMk

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

Prod Riddman

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdSuKogXJOZld5Dzw_9285w

1:54 - How Equivalent Fractions Are Made

4:06 - Example (16/25 = 1120/1750)
6:35 - Where Equivalent Fractions Are Used (A) Dissimilar Fractions. 
8:05 - Where Equivalent Fractions Are Used (B) Simplifying Fractions
8:58 - Further Help (What To Watch Next)

snippet.title: How To Simplify Fractions Using Prime Factorization
snippet.description:
Description box:

What you need to know to understand this lesson: 
1--- How to do Prime Factorization
2--- How to find HCF of 2 numbers 
Check Out My Previoius Videos that go into more detail on these subjects: 

What Is Prime Factorization? https://youtu.be/1MPnDudbMow

How To Find HCF of Two Numbers (using Prime Factorization) https://youtu.be/vHVVs-COFKA

Hi Guys, back with another video. In this lesson you’ll learn how to use PRIME FACTORIZATION to find the Highest Common Factor (or Greatest Common Divisor) of the Numerator and Denominator of a fraction so you can simplify the fraction (also called reducing the fraction).  
Knowing the HCF of two numbers is very useful when you are asked to simplify fractions. If you can find the HCF of the numerator and denominator of a fraction, you can divide both by the HCF and that will give you the fraction reduced to its simplest form. 

The most common way of doing this is by listing the common factors of the numerator and denominator of the fraction and then looking for the Highest Common Factor (HCF), that is, the largest of the common factors. Then one can divide the top and bottom of the fraction using the HCF to simplify the fraction. 

But this becomes difficult if your fraction Numerator and denominator are large numbers. That’s where it is better to simplify the fractions using prime factorization.  

Today You’ll learn how to simplify Fractions using Prime Factorization to find the HCF.  We’ll simplify the fraction 25/48 the common way, and then we will simplify the same fraction using Prime Factorization.  We will also simplify a harder fraction, 1120/1750, using prime factorization. You will see that the prime factorization method is much faster and less confusing for these harder fractions, and, overall, it is a better method for simplifying even simpler fractions.  

Today’s lesson is the final part of the series dealing with Prime Numbers and the benefits of knowing how to  use them.  I’ve linked all of the other lessons below. 

Contents:
0:00 - Lesson objective/ simplifying fractions overview
0:42 - simplifying without Prime Factorization
1:59 - The problem with Large Numbers
2:58 - Using Prime Factorization To simplify 25/48
4:48 - Simplifying Bigger Numbers 1120/1750
8:10 - Other useful Videos



This lesson is part of a series covering Prime Numbers and their uses.  

Check out other lessons in this series: 
How To Find Prime Numbers - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtMwsI0giJ4
Finding Prime Numbers From 1 - 100 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYy3oTE67tQ
What Is Prime Factorization? - https://youtu.be/1MPnDudbMow
How To Find HCF of Two Numbers (using Prime Factorization) -  https://youtu.be/vHVVs-COFKA

snippet.title: How To Find The HCF of Two Numbers  Using Prime Factorization
snippet.description:
In this lesson we’re going to show you how to find the highest common factor of two numbers, by using a method called Prime Factorization.  If you don’t know what prime factorization is, then I’ve linked to my video ‘What is Prime Factorization?’ here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1MPnDudbMow


 and I’ll also link to it at the end of this video.  It’ll help you better understand what’s going on in the lesson.

We’ll look at two sets of numbers, first we’ll find the HCF of 60 and 30, and then the HCF of 1750 and 1120. I’ll cover the basics of common factors first for those who need a reminder of how to find them. You’ll see how to use Prime Factorization to find the HCF of any two numbers, Especially large numbers. 

 There will be one more video in this series where I show you how to use the HCF to simplify fractions, using prime factorization to find the HCF’s.

This lesson is part of a series covering Prime Numbers and their uses.

snippet.title: What Is Prime Factorization?
snippet.description:
In this lesson we will be answering the question; “ what is Prime Factorization “? We will first look at some examples of numbers in the format of Prime Factorization, where all the factors of the number are prime numbers.  Then we will review how to do normal factorization and show that there is a difference between the two.  

Then, using our knowledge of normal factorization, we will take numbers that are factorized the normal way, and then work them so that all of the factors of the number are prime, and that is prime factorization. 

Prime factorization is important to subjects such as simplifying fractions, finding the lowest common denominator of dissimilar fractions, and finding the highest common factor of two numbers, so you must practice and master this skill.  

What you need to know to understand this lesson: 
1--- What Prime Numbers are and how to find them
2--- How to find factors of any number.

This lesson is part of a series covering Prime Numbers.  
Other lessons in this series: 
How To Find Prime Numbers - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtMwsI0giJ4
Finding Prime Numbers From 1 - 100 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYy3oTE67tQ

snippet.title: Finding Prime Numbers From 1 to 100
snippet.description:
Today is a short lesson where I show you how to find prime numbers from 1 to 100 using the process called The Sieve of Eratosthenes. 
In this process, you will be gradually cancelling numbers off the 1 to 100 list by crossing out the multiples of the primes 2, 3, 5 and 7 that are not greater than 100. 

By the time the process is over, the only numbers left are the prime numbers smaller than 100. 

The process is very easy and only requires you to know your times tables for the first four primes, 2, 3, 5, and 7 and only multiples no greater than the number 100.

This lesson does not  cover the basics of how to find prime numbers so if you need to learn about prime numbers in detail or need a refresher click the link below which is a video I made showing you how to find Prime Numbers. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtMwsI0giJ4

After today’s lesson you should find it very easy to find prime numbers between 1 and 100. You can even use it to eliminate larger numbers as not prime with a bit of practice. 

This is the second video in a series where I teach you about prime numbers and their uses.  Other videos in the series deal with Finding The Lowest Common Multiple of 2 or 3 Numbers (Already made - video link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v79EPbER--g  ) , Finding the Highest Common Factor of 2 numbers, how to do Prime Factorization of any number and  how to use prime factors to simplify fractions.  You can subscribe below to be notified of these upcoming videos.

snippet.title: How To Find Prime Numbers
snippet.description:
Hey guys; in today’s lesson we’ll be learning How To Find Prime Numbers. We’ll first discuss where you will find Prime Numbers (Clue: in the Natural numbers), and then we’ll review the properties of Natural numbers and show how those properties help us in finding prime numbers.  I’ll then show you how you can go about looking at individual numbers and working out if they are prime or not.  We’ll also look at some methods for finding the prime numbers that are less than 100, and finally we’ll give a few quick examples of how to use the concepts learned in the lesson.  By the end of the lesson Prime numbers will have been explained and you should then be able to find prime numbers without much difficulty. 


Today’s video is the first in a series, Actually I’ve made one of the videos already before, and I’ll link to it here, but in the rest of the series I will be showing you how to use prime numbers to do prime factorization, that is how to write numbers as a  product of prime factors, how to find the highest common factor of 2 numbers, how to find the Lowest common multiple of 2 or 3 numbers, and finally how to use prime numbers and prime factorization when simplifying fractions. So make sure you’re subscribed and have clicked the notification bell so you can know when I’m releasing a new video.  

Here's the Video showing How to find The LCM of 2 or 3 numbers (using Prime Factorization method in the second half):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v79EPbER--g

snippet.title: How To Find Corresponding And Alternate Angles In Parallel Lines
snippet.description:
Corresponding and alternate angles of parallel lines are the angles that result when you have two parallel lines and you have one straight line that crosses through both of those lines at an angle. 

We'll explain how you identify alternate and corresponding angles, and then I have two example questions for you to try out; you can use what you've learned today to see if you can find the corresponding or alternate angles and use that information to answer the two questions. 

Corresponding anges and Alternate angles come in pairs.  On their own they do not have an identity, but are named corresponding or alternate in relationship to another angle. So a corresponding angle is only such because of how it compares to a reference angle; the same is true of alternate angle. So Corresponding angles and Alternate angles come in pairs, corresponding pairs and alternate pairs and you will learn how to identify these pairs in today's less. 

At the end of the lesson I link to another video where I show how the use of this concept helps us prove that the angles in a triangle add up to 180 degrees. (link also below). 

Video - Proof that the angles in a triangle add up to 180 degrees:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_jhqQ-Ig2s

snippet.title: Sum Of All Angles of a Triangle is 180 degrees (proof)
snippet.description:
In this lesson we will give proof that the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is 180 degrees. This proof is necessary because from the knowledge that the sum of all angles in a triangle is 180 degrees, we can then use triangles and their angle measurements to calculate all other types of polygons, whether they be squares, quadrilaterals, Pentagons etc. 

What you need to know to understand this proof: 

To  understand this proof there are two things you need to know. 

1)t ‘the sum of all angles on a straight line is 180 degrees’, and
2) You also need to know how to find alternate angles

If you are unsure about how to find alternate angles, here is a link to my video on the subject where I discuss the basics of both Corresponding angles, AND alternate angles: 
https://youtu.be/LX0By_fUI_c

Feel free to check that video out after you have watched today’s lesson on how we prove that the sum of all angles in a triangle is 180 degrees. 

Once we have shown the proof we will then look at a few examples of how you can use triangles to determine the sum of all angles in other polygons such as Pentagons and Hexagons and even oddly shaped polygons. 

For a full understanding of why the triangle angles of 180 degrees is so important, I also recommend watching my video on why the formula (n-2)180° works for finding the sum of angles in ANY polygon and how the sum of angles in a triangle is related to this formula. Here’s the link to that video: 
https://youtu.be/8akzl9oMjQo


Feel free to follow on to that video after today’s lesson. 

Contents: 

0:00 - Introduction - What You’ll learn (The sum of all angles of a triangle is 180 - Proof)
0:18 - Knowledge You Need Beforehand
1:02 - Preparing the Triangle Layout for the Proof
3:00 - Finding Alternate Angles Of The Triangle’s Inner Angles
4:11 - Showing the Alternate Angles and one inner angle = 180 degrees
5:15 - Finishing up; A + B + C, Sum of angles of a triangle is 180 degrees
5:45 - Using Triangles’ sum of 180 degrees to measure other Polygons

snippet.title: How To Find angles of a quadrilateral
snippet.description:
In today's lesson we will be learning how to find missing angles of a quadrilateral. We consider one example and use the fact that all the angles of a triangle add up to 180 degrees and show how this helps us know the angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360 degrees. 

After today's lesson you should easily be able to find a missing angle of a quadrilateral as long as you are given the other three angles.

snippet.title: How To Find The Angles of an ISOSCELES Triangle
snippet.description:
Here’s a quick lesson on how to find the angles of an isosceles triangle, if you are given the size of just one the angles. Finding Angles in an isosceles triangle is not too difficult, you just need to remember that the angles of a triangle add up to 180 degrees, and then remember that in an isosceles triangle, there are two identical angles and one angle that differs in value from the identical other two. 

If the given angle is the unique angle (the angle that sits between the sides of equal length, or in the position in between the two strokes indicating an isosceles triangle), then to find the other angles in the isosceles triangle just subtract the value of the unique angle from 180 degrees and then divide the result by 2. The number you get will be the size of each of the identical angles. 

If on the other hand the given angle is not between the sides of equal length, then it must be one of the two identical angles (so the other angle that sits between two sides of different lengths must also have the same value of the given angle. Therefore, to find the remaining angle of the isosceles triangle you need to double the value of the given angle and then subtract the result from 180 degrees. That will give you the value of the ‘unique’ angle that sits between the two edges of equal length. 

If you find these examples easy, I have added a linked  video at the end of this lesson with a harder example where none of the internal angles in the isosceles triangle are given, and the only angle available is an outside angle. Check that out so you can really put your knowledge of triangles to use.  



Contents: 
0:00 - Introduction
0:09 Example 1
2:57 Example 2
4:50 Rules for calculating missing angles
6:00 Outro and Next Video - harder example

snippet.title: How To Find The Lowest Common Multiple of 2 or 3 numbers ( TWO METHODS)
snippet.description:
In this video I’ll be showing you how to find the lowest common multiple of Two AND 3 numbers. The ability to find the LCM of two or more numbers is useful for when you need to add or subtract fractions with different denominators. 

Today we’re going to be looking at two methods for finding the Lowest Common Multiple of 2 or 3 numbers.  

The steps to the first Method are: 

1) List List the first few multiples of each number 
2) Look for multiples that appear on both lists. (364)

I find it better to list the multiples of the largest number first, and then work down to smaller numbers, and once I have a few numbers in both all lists of multiples, I look for the lowest number which appears on all three lists.  This is the lowest common multiple of all 3 numbers. 

This first method is straightforward, but might get difficult if you have large numbers and you aren’t an expert at your times tables since you’ll need to write very large multiples.  There’s an alternative method you can use for finding the lowest common multiple if your numbers are awkward and I list the steps to the second method below. 


1) Write each number as a product of prime factors, and 
2) Multiply the prime factors together, to find the LCM

In order to use this method you must know how to write numbers as a product of PRIME FACTORS. You must then use the method indicated in the videos for working out step 2, which numbers you multiply together; what to leave in the multiplication and what to leave out. 

After watching this video you should be able to find the lowest common multiple of not just 2 or 3 but any amount of numbers as long as you take your time; and of course, this will also help you in the process of adding or subtracting fractions with different denominators, which requires the knowledge of how to find the lowest common multiple of different denominators. 

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1


Video Contents

0:00 - Example 1) LCM of 4 and 5
0:40 - List Multiples of Both Numbers
1:24 - Pick Lowest Common Multiples of 4 and 5

2:22 - Example 2) LCM of 2, 4, and 5
2:30 - List Multiples of all 3 Numbers
2:47 - Picking LCM of 2, 4 and 5

3:45 - Example 3 ) LCM of 24, 15 and 9
3:58 - List Multiples of 24, 15 and 9
4:09 - Looking for common multiples of  24, 15 and 9

5:42 - Example 3 With Alternative Method
6:26 - Rewrite Numbers as Product of PRIME FACTORS
6:46 - Creating a PRIME FACTOR Table
7:59 - Calculate LCM by Multiplying Factors Together

9:03 - Which Method is Better?

snippet.title: How to Add 3 Fractions with Different Denominators (using  the Lowest Common Denominator)
snippet.description:
In Today's lesson we will be learning how to add 3 Fractions with different denominators.  Previously we learned how to add two fractions with different denominators using a simple cross multiplication method, and then a more challenging method using the lowest common Denominator of two denominators. In this video we extend that to adding 3 fractions with different denominators using the Lowest Common Multiple method. I've included two examples that we will work on. 

The steps for adding 3 fractions with different denominators are below: 
1) Find the Lowest Common Denominator of the three Fractions
2) Convert The 3 different denominators to the Lowest Common Denominator
3) Convert the Numerators so the values of your fractions don't change when you change the denominators to the LCD
4) Replace your original 3 fractions with different denominators to the equivalent fractions, all of which now have the common denominator.
5) Convert the result to a mixed number if it is an improper fraction, and simplify if possible. 

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1



What you should already know: 
1) How to Add Fractions with Different Denominators (two fractions)
2) How to Convert Improper Fractions to Mixed Numbers
3) How to simplify or reduce fractions (particularly how to spot whether simplifying is needed or not)

We'll be doing two examples in this video

Example 1:  
1/2 + 2/5 + 3/4

Example 2:
1/15 + 3/10 + 2/5  

Video Contents: 
0:00 Introduction
0:46 - List of Steps For adding Fractions
1:02 - Example #1
1:25 - Find LCD
2:25 - Convert Denominators to LCD
3:08 - Convert Original Numerators
4:07 - Replace Original Fractions
4:55 - Simplify & Convert Result

6:17 Example #2
6:23 - Find LCD
7:08 - Convert Denominators to LCD

snippet.title: How to Add Unlike Fractions   FASTER - No LCD
snippet.description:
In Today's video I will show you a very easy way to add fractions with different denominators, often called 'dissimilar' fractions or 'unlike' fractions. We will Add Fractions with Unlike Denominators using no Lowest Common Multiple (LCM). you can add Dissimilar Fractions FAST using this method. Being able to add fractions with different denominators is an important tool which will help you with GCSE maths fractions questions.  

You can't go wrong with this simple method when trying to add two dissimilar fractions.  In the Next video we will look at how to add fractions with different denominators using the lcm method

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

Contents: 
00:02 - Example 1 ( 2/3 + 3/7 )

snippet.title: How To Add Fractions With Different Denominators Using Lowest Common Multiples
snippet.description:
Adding Fractions with different denominators can seem confusing at first. You know how to add fractions with the same denominator, that’s easy, but these fractions are unlike and therefore have different denominators. How do you add these kinds of fractions?  You might think that you have to add the numerators like you do with similar fractions, but that’s going to get you the wrong answer. 

We can solve additional problems with unlike fractions by using the lowest common denominator of your fractions. In today’s lesson I show you how to find the Lowest Common Denominator of two fractions with different denominators, and how to  use this denominator (normally abbreviated to the LCD) to create equivalent fractions of your original unlike fractions, which will be much easier to add, because the resulting equivalent fractions will all have the same denominator. 

You will then be able to add the fractions to come up with an answer. This process will make adding fractions with different denominators a lot easier. So, watch and enjoy.

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

0:00 Introduction 
0:54 Easier Method (without LCD)
1:35 LCD Method
2:53 Using LCD to convert both fractions
5:03 Subscribe Break
5:47 Rewriting The Original Question
6:50 Why We Use the Lowest Common Multiple
9:05 BONUS Question

snippet.title: How to add Mixed Numbers with Different Denominators (step by step)
snippet.description:
In this video I will be showing you how to add Mixed Numbers with unlike fractions step by step. Mixed numbers are composed of whole numbers and fractions. They are like a sum with a whole number and a fraction added. For example 3 + 1/2, which we would call 'three and a half'. When we are adding mixed numbers with unlike fractions, the fractions on the end of the whole numbers are 'NOT' similar, they have differing denominators. So we must use our knowledge of how to add unlike fractions while using the method in the video. The steps required for adding mixed number with unlike fractions are as follows: 
1. Make two columbs 
2.  Separate mixed numbers into whole numbers and fractions
3. Write the whole numbers in the left columb 
4.  Write the unlike fractions in the right columb 
5.   Add the numbers in the left Column 
6.  Add the numbers in the right column (simplify answer and convert to a mixed number if the result is an improper fraction) Note: Cross multiplication method will sometimes cause
7.  add the results from left columb and right columb that's your answer. 

Subscribe to TinyMaths here: https://www.youtube.com/c/TinyMaths/videos?sub_confirmation=1

What you should already know before trying to add mixed numbers with unlike denominators: 
1. How to add fractions with different denominators: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwbNL7iyUfQ
2. How to simplify Fractions using the HCF (highest common factor) of both denominators (not my Channel; this is The Organic Chemistry Tutor channel):https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcEwj5_v75g
3. How to convert improper fractions to mixed numbers: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9Cquv2ZGRA&t=168s

Example No 1

51/2 + 31/3

1. Create columns right and left.  (you can separate the columns with a gap in the middle and put plus signs between the totals at the bottom. In left column put 5 and 3, In the right column put  1/2   and 1/3 
2. Then 5 + 3 = 8
3. Then 1/2 +1/3. We need a note on how to add unlike Fractions (relate previous video). Now since our Fractions have different denominators we need to know how to add unlike fractions.  We can use the simple method for adding these two fractions. Simply Multiply the left denominator by the right denominator. This gives us 2x3 = 6; and now we cross multiply the numerators with the denominators, so left numerator x right denominator giving 1x3 and right numerator x left denominator giving 1x2 and we now add these together on top of our new denominator so we get (2+3)/6 = 5/6
4. Resulting Fraction is 5/6 (no need to simplify – no common factors)
5. Not an improper fraction so we can't convert into a mixed number
6. Left Column + right column = 8 + 5/6 = 85/6
Therefore our final answer to the problem is 51/2 + 31/3  = 85/6

Example No 2
53/4 + 67/10

I said smash the like button, comment and share so the channel can grow and we can help more people (use the screen tap animation for this) 
Go through steps 1-6 using 53/4 + 37/10
1. Create columns right and left.  (you can separate the columns with a gap in the middle and put plus signs between the totals at the bottom. In left column put 5 and 6, In the right column put  3/4  and 7/10 
2. Then 5 + 6 = 11
3. Then 3/4 + 7/10 We can use the simple method for adding these two fractions. Simply Multiply the left denominator by the right denominator. This gives us 4x10 = 40, which is our new denominator; and now we cross multiply the numerators with the denominators, so left numerator x right denominator giving 3x10=30, and right numerator x left denominator giving 7x4=28, and we now add these together on top of our new denominator so we get (30+28)/40 = 58/40. 
4. This fraction can simplify  using the highest common factor which is 2. So divide top and bottom by 2 and we get 29/20 which is an equivalent fraction to 58/40. 
5.  We haven't finished yet though, because we now have an improper Fraction.  Now we can view our fraction as a basic division dividing 29 by 20. So 20 goes into 29 once, leaving a remainder of 9 so the solution 29/20 can be rewritten as 1+9/20
6. Now we have results in both columns all we have to do is add the values from the Whole number column to the values from the fractions column. So left Column + right Column = 11 + (1+ 9/20) = 129/20 
Therefore  our final answer to the problem is 53/4 + 37/10 = 129/20 
Now for those of you who have managed to stick around, thanks for doing so, and NOW, here is the bonus question, I'm taking a fraction from each of our two previous problems and creating a new problem, here it is 53/4 +31/3 
Can you solve this problem using the steps we learned in today's video? See if you can do it! And don't forget; put your answer in the comment section.

Video Contents: 
0:00 Introduction 
0:51 Overview
1:06 What you need to already know
1:21 Example No 1 (5*1/2 + 3*1/3)
4:14 Example No 2 ( 5*3/4 + 6*7/10)
8:58 Bonus Question
9:28 Time to say goodbye

snippet.title: How To Add Fractions With Different Denominators - No LCM Method
snippet.description:
In Today's video I will show you a very easy way to add fractions with different denominators, often called 'dissimilar' fractions or 'unlike' fractions. We will Add Fractions with Unlike Denominators using no Lowest Common Multiple (LCM). you can add Dissimilar Fractions FAST using this method. Being able to add fractions with different denominators is an important tool which will help you with GCSE maths fractions questions.  

You can't go wrong with this simple method when trying to add two fractions with different denominators using no LCM.  In the Next video we will look at how to add fractions with different denominators using the lcm method

Contents:
0:00 - Step 1- Finding The Denominator
1:05 - Step 2 - Working out The Two Numerators
2:09 - Step 3 - Putting It All Together
3:18 - Summarizing Everything
4:05 - Final Thoughts - This Won't Always Work

snippet.title: How To Find Corresponding And Alternate Angles
snippet.description:
Today we introduce Corresponding Angles and  Alternate Angles and see how they help us prove the rule that all the angles of a triangle add up to 180°. This fundamental rule enables us to use triangles to determine the sum of all angles in any polygon. 

00:00 - Introduction to ME, Tiny Maths
01:06 - The essentials (of Corresponding and Alternate angles)
02:40 - Corresponding Angles
04:58 - Alternate Angles
09:30 - Proving angles of a Triangle add up to 180°

snippet.title: External Angles Problem   Can You Solve This One?
snippet.description:
Today we solve angles on a huge polygon, one with 18 sides. We'll use two methods; one using our knowledge of the sum of external angles, and the other using our knowledge of the sum of internal angles of a regular polygon.

Contents - 
0:00 - Introduction
1:54 - Method #1  (use the fact that the sum of all exterior angles on a polygon is 360°)
7:08 - Method #2 (use the fact that all interior angles of a regular polygon are equal)

snippet.title: Sum of External angles of ANY polygon
snippet.description:
Today we show how the sum of the external angles of ANY polygon is 360°. 
We then use this rule to calculate external and internal angles of an irregular pentagon

0:00 - Intro
1:06 - Sum of External Angles 
4:22 - External Angles Problem

snippet.title: External Angles of a POLYGON
snippet.description:
Today we discuss how to find the values of external angles on a polygon. We also see an interesting situation where the sum of all the external angles is 360°. We discuss the importance of this in an upcoming video.

Contents of this Video

0:00 Introduction to External Angles
1:13 Pentagon External Angles
6:30 Quadrilateral External Angles

snippet.title: Finding Angles in A POLYGON: why (n-2)*180° ?
snippet.description:
Today we look at the formula (n-2)*180°  and learning why the formula works for finding angles in a polygon.  Finding Angles in a Polygon might seem confusing at first but once you learn that this formula can always be used, and why it is used, the Angles in a Polygon will be very easy to find and you will understand why a particular polygon has a particular sum of angles. 

Video Chapters

00:25 - intro: Finding TRIANGLES within polygons
02:24 - Triangle
04:52 - Quadrilateral
06:30 - Pentagon
09:11 - Heptagon ( 7 sided polygon)
13:09 - Bonus shape (irregular pentagon, more difficult example)

snippet.title: Angles of ANY Polygon Made EASY
snippet.description:
Today we discuss the easiest way to find the sum of angles in ANY polygon, (n-2)*180. 
This works for ALL polygons and is quick and easy. We will explain why this works in the next video in this 'Angles' series.

snippet.title: Angles of An OCTAGON: Irregular Octagon Actually
Angles of a POLYGON
snippet.description: Now moving to shapes with more sides than triangles and quadrilaterals, we move to polygons; irregular polygons and how to find the sum of their angles.

snippet.title: Angles of A SCALENE Triangle
snippet.description:
The Scalene triangle. All three sides have different lengths and therefore all three angles are different. Today we learn how to find missing scalene triangle angles.

snippet.title: ISOSCELES Triangles   More Difficult Angles
snippet.description: One more examples of finding missing angles on a triangle using our knowledge of angles, straight lines etc.

snippet.title: Angles of an ISOSCELES Triangle
snippet.description: Building on our previous lesson, we find the angles inside an Isosceles triangle using various techniques.

snippet.title: Triangles Equilateral, Isosceles and Scalene
snippet.description:
This lesson is about the basic triangles; Scalene, Isosceles and Equilateral. 
We will see how we can  use our understanding of these types of triangles to calculate missing angles within a triangle.

snippet.title: Improper Fractions, AND How To Rewrite Them As Mixed Numbers
snippet.description:
Today we deal with Improper fractions and how to convert them to mixed numbers. 
It is essential to know how to do this because the technique will be useful if we have to add different improper fractions which we will do in later lessons.

snippet.title: Multiplying Fractions by Cancellation
snippet.description: This is a useful method to use while multiplying fractions.  Especially when numerator/denominator are not small.

snippet.title: How To Add Dissimilar Fractions - Part 1
snippet.description: As a follow up to the lessons on Equivalent Fractions, and Lowest Common Multiples prior to that, we bring it all together and show how it can be used to solve dissimilar (unlike) fractions, fractions which have different denominators.
